description: From New Latin intrōvertere, from intro- (“within”) and vertere (“to turn”). Popularized as a psychological term by the German works of Carl Jung.

adjectives.description: introvert (comparative more introvert, superlative most introvert)

examples: They were noticeably more introvert, schizoid and desurgent in temperament.

entries.meaning: (zoology) An organ or other body part that is or can be turned inside out, especially an anterior portion of some annelid worms capable of retraction.
examples: Important distinctions which obtain amongst the various ‘introverts’ or intro- and e-versible tubes so frequently met with in animal bodies.

entries.meaning: (psychology) An introverted person: one who is considered more thoughtful than social, with a personality more inwardly than outwardly directed; one who often prefers to have time in non-social situations.
examples: An Extravert can hardly conceive the necessity which compels the Introvert to conquer the world by means of a system.

verbs.description: introvert (third-person singular simple present introverts, present participle introverting, simple past and past participle introverted)

entries.meaning: To think about internal or spiritual matters.
examples: […]  the Soul being straight, introverted  […]  into itself, and easily conforming to God's will and time  […]

entries.meaning: (zoology) To withdraw an organ or body part within itself or its base.
examples: His awkward gait, his introverted toes,Bent knees, round shoulders, and dejected looks  […]
